title: Music in New Orleans for Saturday, Oct. 3, 2015: Rhiannon Giddens at Tipitina's
text:
On Saturday, Oct. 3, the options for live music in New Orleans include a ball hosted by a famous local Hall, a funk legend, and a fast-rising new folk music star.
Preservation Hall Ball, Civic Theater, 9 p.m.
The Preservation Hall Ball benefits the famed French Quarter jazz hall's foundation, which supports various music education outreach programs. The idea is to bring together a diverse roster of New Orleans and New Orleans-loving musicians for one-of-a-kind collaborations. Scheduled performers this year include Meshell Ndegeocello; Greg Dulli, Dave Rosser and Rick Nelson of the Afghan Whigs, joined by guitarist Bailey Smith of the Morning 40 Federation; Deacon John Moore; Ivan Neville; the Pinettes Brass Band; Griz; vocalist Corey Glover of Living Colour; and, of course, the Preservation Hall Jazz Band.
Rhiannon Giddens , Tipitina's, 9 p.m.
Rhiannon Giddens is that rare opera-trained vocalist who changed gears entirely to play traditional Appalachian string music and protest songs. Giddens was a founder of the Carolina Chocolate Drops, a string ensemble that focused on traditional, rural African-American music; she contributed fiddle and banjo, in addition to her remarkable voice. She delivered a star-making solo turn during "Another Day, Another Time," the all-star concert inspired by the Coen brothes film "Inside Llewyn Davis." She joined Elvis Costello, Marcus Mumford and Jim James for the T-Bone Burnett-produced "Lost on the River: the New Basement Tapes" project, which completed unfinished Bob Dylan songs. Burnett produced Giddens' 2015 solo debut album, "Tomorrow Is My Turn," on which she puts her stamp on songs associated with Dolly Parton, Nina Simone and Patsy Cline, among others. Leyla McCalla is also on the bill with Giddens at Tipitina's.
Also on Saturday:
George Clinton & Parliament-Funkadelic kick out the jams at the House of Blues.
Right next door, the Electric Six plug in at The Parish.
Rap duo Run the Jewels throws down at Republic New Orleans.
Harmonica man Johnny Sansone powers his band at Chickie Wah Wah.
The Ike Stubblefield Organ Trio is at Snug Harbor.
